bestBHT.bht: The Father does not vivify any, but entrusts all quickening power to the Son. The judgment mentioned is about bestowing everlasting life and the Son's role as Judge of the living and the dead. Raising the dead is a sign of the Son's authority in judgment. All judgment, including administration and the final award of condemnation, is given to the Son by the Father. This prerogative of judgment for Christ is not new but has been claimed before. Ultimately, the Son's ability to judge reflects His divine nature and equality with the Father.

Henry Alford: In the words neither doth is implied, that as the Father does not Himself, by His own proper act, vivify any, but commits all quickening power to the Son.
And judgment contains eminently in itself the 'whom He will,'—when the act of quickening is understood—as it must be now—of bestowing everlasting life.
Again, the raising of the outwardly dead is to be understood as a sign that He who works it is appointed Judge of quick and dead, for it is a part of the office of that Judge.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: For neither doth the Father judge any man.

The same 'thing was meant in the former verse of the quickening of the dead'—both acts being done, not by the Father and the Son, as though twice done, but by the Father through the Son as His voluntary Agent.
All judgment—judgment in its most comprehensive sense, or as we should say, all administration.
Albert Barnes: He affirmed John 5:17 that he had the same power over the Sabbath that his Father had; in John 5:19, that he did the same things as the Father; in John 5:21 particularly that he had the same power to raise the dead.
The power of judging the world implies ability to search the heart, and omniscience to understand the motives of all actions.
This is a work which none but a divine being can do, and it shows, therefore, that the Son is equal to the Father.
Marvin Vincent: The A. V. misses the climax in ouJude; not even the Father, who might be expected to be judge."
The habitual word for the bestowment of the privileges and functions of the Son.
John Calvin: The Father governs the world in the person of the Son, and exercises dominion by his hand.
No change took place in the Father, when he appointed Christ to be supreme King and Lord of heaven and earth.
Christ is placed before our eyes as a lively image of the invisible God.
Philip Schaff: The Father showeth the Son all things that Himself doeth: from this complete manifestation nothing is excepted, not even that final arbitrament which is the prerogative of the Supreme.
By 'judgment,' as in chap. John 3:17-19, we must certainly understand a judgment that issues in condemnation.
All judgment future and present, the final award with all that foreshadows it, the Father hath given, by a bestowal which can never be revoked, unto the Son.
Archibald T. Robertson: He hath given all judgement unto the Son."
See this prerogative claimed for Christ already in John 3:17.
See the picture of Christ as Judge of men in Matthew 25:31-46.
John Gill: He judges all men, and justifies and acquits whom he pleases, but not without his Son; but through his justifying righteousness, which he imputes to them; in doing which he appears to he a just judge, and to do right...

and which he exercises by giving ordinances peculiar to it, such as baptism and the Lord's supper; and by enacting laws, and prescribing rules for the discipline of his house, over which he is as a Son...

and will pass a most righteous and decisive sentence upon all: now for such a trust, and such a work as this, whether the particular government of the church, or the general judgment of the world, he would not be fit, was he not God equal with the Father...
John Wesley: For neither doth the Father judge — Not without the Son: but he doth judge by that man whom he hath ordained, Acts 17:31.

bhtAttempts.bht: In John 5:22, it is implied that the Father does not Himself vivify any, but rather entrusts all quickening power to the Son. The judgment mentioned in this verse encompasses the act of bestowing eternal life. The Son's role as Judge of the living and the dead is further illustrated through raising the physically dead as a sign of His authority. All judgment, including administration and the final award of condemnation, is given to the Son by the Father. This prerogative of judgment for Christ is not a new concept, as seen in John 3:17 and Matthew 25:31-46. Ultimately, the Son's ability to judge is a testament to His divine nature and equality with the Father.

The Father does not vivify any, but entrusts all quickening power to the Son. The judgment mentioned is about bestowing eternal life. Raising the dead is a sign of the Son's role as Judge. All judgment, including administration and the final award of condemnation, is given to the Son by the Father. This prerogative of judgment for Christ is not new but has been claimed before. The Son's ability to judge reflects His divine nature and equality with the Father.

The Father bestows all quickening power to the Son, who is the appointed Judge of the living and the dead. The act of raising the physically dead serves as a sign of the Son's authority in judgment. This encompasses the administration of all judgment, including the final condemnation. Such a trust and work reveal the Son's divine nature and equality with the Father.

Raising the dead is a sign of the Son's authority in judgment. All judgment, including administration and the final award of condemnation, is given to the Son by the Father. This prerogative of judgment for Christ is not new but has been claimed before. Ultimately, the Son's ability to judge reflects His divine nature and equality with the Father.

The Father does not vivify any, but entrusts all quickening power to the Son. The judgment mentioned is about bestowing everlasting life. Raising the dead is a sign of the Son's authority as Judge. All judgment, including administration and the final award of condemnation, is given to the Son by the Father. This prerogative of judgment for Christ has been claimed before. The Son's ability to judge reflects His divine nature and equality with the Father.
